Fischer–Tropsch synthesis over cobalt catalysts supported on nanostructured alumina with various morphologies Chengchao Liu a Jinlin Li a ⁎ Yuhua Zhang a b Sufang Chen b c Junjiang Zhu a Kongyong Liew a a Key Laboratory of Catalysis and Materials Science of the State Ethnic Affairs & Commission Ministry of Education, South-Central University for Nationalities, Wuhan, Hubei 430074, China b College of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Materials Science Soochow University, Suzhou 215123, China c Key Laboratory for Green Chemical Process of Ministry of Education, School of Chemical Engineering and Pharmacy, Wuhan Institute of Technology, Wuhan, Hubei 430073, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 27 67843016; fax: +86 27 67842752. Graphical abstract The cobalt catalyst supported on the nanostructured alumina increased the CO conversion by 20–30%, compared to commercial alumina. Among the nanostructured alumina, the nanofiber supported catalyst has improved stability through the large, stable and interconnected bird nest-like pore structures with large cobalt particle size and showed the best catalytic performance. Highlights ► The morphologies of nanostructured Al2O3 effect on cobalt catalysts for FTS were reported. ► Nano-Al2O3 supports undergo reconstruction during the catalyst preparation. ► Nano-Al2O3 improved CO conversion by 20–30% compared to commercial Al2O3. ► Al2O3 nanofibers have improved catalyst stability through bird nest-like pores. Nanostructured aluminas with controllable morphologies were prepared and used as support of cobalt catalysts for Fischer–Tropsch synthesis. The supported cobalt catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method and characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), temperature programmed reduction (TPR), N2 adsorption–desorption, hydrogen chemisorption and oxygen titration. Catalytic activity of the cobalt catalysts for Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) was evaluated on a fixed bed reactor. It was found that the nanostructured alumina supports undergo reconstruction during the catalyst preparation resulting in catalysts having high dispersion after reduction. The cobalt catalyst supported on the nanostructured alumina increased the CO conversion by 20–30%, compared to commercial alumina. Among the nanostructured catalysts, the alumina nanorods supported catalyst, shows the best dispersion and highest CO initial conversion. Our work disclosed that the alumina nanofibers supported catalysts have larger, stable and interconnected bird nest-like pores. In addition, the structure exhibited higher stability and lower methane selectivity for FTS. Keywords Fischer–Tropsch synthesis Cobalt catalysts Nanostructured alumina Morphology 1 Introduction Catalytic synthesis of liquid fuels and valuable chemicals, using natural gas and coal, as well as renewable biomass resources by Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is a well-established technology. The development of novel catalysts with good performance is the key to improving FT technologies and it is one of the main focuses in the academic community. The typical active metals used in Fischer–Tropsch catalysts are Fe, Co, and Ru, although several other metals, such as Ni and Rh, also exhibit activities [1]. Among these metals are supported cobalt catalysts, which show good selectivity to long-chain paraffin, strong resistance to deactivation for FTS and low activity for water gas shift reaction [2–4]. Various supports, such as silica [5], alumina [6], titania [7], carbon [8,9], magnesia [10] and zeolites [11], have been used to enhance the catalytic activity and selectivity of these cobalt catalysts. It was found that the reducibility and dispersions of supported cobalt catalysts were significantly influenced by the type and structure of the support and thereby influenced the activity and selectivity [12]. Thus, selecting a suitable material as support of cobalt catalyst for FTS is a crucial step. Alumina is one of the most frequently used supports in FTS, due to its good mechanical properties, strong resistance to attrition and controllable surface properties [13]. Many good works have been reported with the effect of alumina as a support of cobalt catalyst for FTS. It was found that the surface area [14], porosity [6,15,16], crystallite phase [17], as well as surface chemical properties [18] of the alumina support, influences significantly the catalytic performances of the catalysts. For example, Xiong et al. [15] reported that alumina with larger pore sizes, leads to larger Co3O4 particle sizes. Borg et al. [19] studied the effect of γ-Al2O3 support variables on Fischer–Tropsch synthesis performance, discovered that the size of the Co3O4 cobalt particles was controlled by the support pore size. Rane et al. [17] observed that cobalt catalysts supported on α- and δ-Al2O3, show higher C5+ selectivity, than those supported on γ- and θ-Al2O3. However, there are scarcely any works focusing on the effect of morphology of nanostructured alumina support on performance for cobalt Fischer–Tropsch synthesis catalysts. As far as we know, only Martínez et al. [14] recently found that RuCo catalyst supported on nanofibrous alumina, showed higher dispersion and macroporosity than that supported on commercial alumina. Herein, in this work, nanostructured alumina with large porosity and various morphologies were synthesized and used as support of cobalt catalyst for FTS. The effect of morphology of nanostructured alumina support on performance of the prepared catalysts will be discussed in detail within throughout this reported research. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of support Nanostructured alumina was synthesized with the following procedures. Typically, 5g Al(NO3)3·9H2O, was dissolved in 100ml anhydrous ethanol, while stirring. The solution was then heated to 353K and ammonium carbonate solution (1moll−1) was added drop-wise, or poured all at once, with the pH controlled at 7.5, 8.5 and 9.5. The resulting sol was continuously stirred for 2h and aged at 353K, for 24h. After that, the products were filtered and washed with de-ionized water, followed by anhydrous ethanol several times. The white precipitates were dried at 383K, for 12h and calcined at 873K (heating rate of 2Kmin−1) for 5h, in static air. The obtained support was denoted as Al2O3-(n), where n equaled F, R, H and P, represented fibers, rods, hybrids and particles, respectively. Next, commercial alumina (>99.0%, Sasol, Z600200, Germany), denoted as Al2O3-(C), was used for comparison. 2.2 Preparation of catalyst The catalyst samples were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of the respective nanostructured γ-alumina, with the desired amount of aqueous cobalt nitrate. The catalysts were dried at 393K, for 12h, followed by calcination at 623K, for 6h. The cobalt loading in the catalyst was 15wt%. These samples were denoted as Co/Al2O3-(n). 2.3 Support and catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns for the samples were done on a Brukers advanced-D8 diffractometer, using monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.54056Å), equipped with a Vanter-1 detector and operated at 40kV and 40mA. The diffraction was recorded between 2θ =10° and 80° with a ramp of 0.016°. Crystallite phases were determined by comparing the diffraction patterns with those in the standard powder XRD files (JCPDS). Co3O4 particle size was calculated using the Scherrer equation (d =(0.89λ/B cos θ)(180°/π)), from the most intense Co3O4 peak (2θ =36.9°). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of the samples were obtained with a FEI Tecnai G2-20 instrument. The samples were prepared by depositing a drop of the dispersion of the powder in ethanol with ultrasonication onto a copper microscope grid, covered with perforated carbon and dried in air for several minutes. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were obtained with a Quantachrome Autosorb-1-C-TCD-MS instrument, at 77K. The samples were degassed at 473K, for 6h prior to the N2 physisorption experiment. The specific surface area was calculated using the Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) model for adsorption data, in a relative pressure range of 0.05–0.30. Pore volumes were calculated from the adsorption data at relative pressure (P/P0) of 0.995. The pore size distribution was estimated using the Barret–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method from the desorption branches of the isotherms. H2 temperature programmed reduction (TPR) experiments were performed using a Quantachrome Autosorb-1-C-TCD-MS instrument. The calcined catalysts (0.12g) were first flushed with argon at 423K, for 1h, to remove traces of water and then cooled to 323K. Subsequently, the sample was reduced from 323K to 1073K (held 30min), at a heating rate of 10Kmin−1 under 10% H2/Ar mixture, with a flow rate of 30mlmin−1. The H2 consumption (TCD signal) was recorded automatically by a PC. Hydrogen chemisorption and oxygen titration measurement were performed using the Zeton Altamira AMI-200 unit. The catalysts were reduced in flowing H2 at 723K, for 12h, then cooled to 373K, under hydrogen gas flow and purged with argon and held at this temperature under flowing Ar, in order to desorb the remaining chemisorbed H2. Moreover, the TCD signal was recorded until it returned to the baseline. Subsequently, an oxygen titration procedure was performed. The reduced catalyst was reoxidized at 723K, by purging it with oxygen pulses until no further consumption of O2, was detected by the TCD located downstream. The methods to calculate the cobalt catalyst dispersion and reduction degree have been reported previously [15]. 2.4 Fischer–Tropsch synthesis FTS was performed in a stainless steel fixed-bed reactor (id=12mm) at 483K and 1.0MPa. The catalysts (ca. 0.5g) were mixed with 5g of inert silicon carbide particles to improve the temperature distribution. The samples were reduced in situ in a H2 flow (6NLh−1 g−1, 298K, 0.1MPa), at atmospheric pressure. The reactor temperature was raised from room temperature to 373K at 2Kmin−1, then to 723K, at a rate of 1Kmin−1. After 10h of reduction at 723K, the reactor was cooled to 373K. At that temperature, the system pressure was increased to 1.0MPa and synthesis gas of molar ratio H2/CO=2 were introduced into the reactor with space velocity of 4SLg−1 h−1 (273K, 0.1MPa). The reactor temperature was increased slowly to 483K. The resulting effluent gaseous products were analyzed online using an Agilent MicroGC 3000A gas chromatograph (GC) equipped, with a TCD detector. The liquid product analysis was performed with an Agilent 6890GC, equipped with a FID detector. The solid wax was dissolved in dimethylbenzene and analyzed with an Agilent 4890GC. The reported activity and selectivity data were obtained at close to a steady state after at least 60h of reaction. The hydrocarbon selectivity was calculated by the total carbon mass balance. Notwithstanding, the methods to calculate hydrocarbon selectivity have been reported previously [15]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of support 3.1.1 X-ray powder diffraction XRD Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the prepared and commercial alumina in the range of 2θ =10–80°. The diffraction peaks at 37.6°, 39.5°, 45.7° and 67.0° are attributed to the γ-Al2O3 phase (JCPDS: 47-1308). The relatively broad peak at 67.0° indicates they have similar γ-Al2O3 phases. Rane et al. [17], has suggested that the alumina phase affected the performances of the cobalt catalysts. In this research, the effect of alumina phases on catalysts performances during the FTS reactions could thus, be completely excluded. 3.1.2 Nitrogen adsorption–desorption The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the prepared and commercial alumina are shown in Fig. 2 . The isotherms were of type IV, with H3 and H4 hysteresis loops, indicating typical slit-type pores of interparticle voids, generated in solids of corrugated plate or, fiber-like morphology [14]. For Al2O3-P, Al2O3-H and Al2O3-R, the two hysteresis loops in the isotherms indicate the presence of hierarchical mesopores. The pore size distributions were obtained from the desorption branch of the isotherms, utilizing the BJH method as shown in Fig. 2. The samples displayed bimodal pore size distributions with pore diameters of 7.3 and 50.0nm, for Al2O3-P, 6.9 and 39.7nm, for Al2O3-H, 7.4 and 20.3nm, for Al2O3-R, while only one broad distribution with pore size ranging from 7.3 to 35.8nm, was observed for sample Al2O3-F. The commercial alumina Al2O3-C, displays a unimodal pore size distribution at around 7.4nm. The textural parameters of all support and catalysts samples are shown in Table 1 . The prepared aluminas and commercial alumina have similar surface area in the range of 260–290m2 g−1, while the prepared alumina have large pore volumes (1.80–2.41cm3 g−1), compared to the commercial one (0.91cm3 g−1). 3.1.3 Transmission electron microscopy TEM images of the prepared and commercial alumina are presented in Fig. 3a–e. The morphology of the alumina sample was affected both by the addition method of (NH4)2CO3 and pH values of the sol (show in Table 2 ). Al2O3-P, is composed mainly of the spherical nanoparticles with an average diameter of 6–8nm and highly developed porous structures between the particles. Another example is Al2O3-H, which consists of a mixture of spherical nanoparticles, with an average diameter of 6–8nm and nanorods, with diameters of 6–8nm and lengths of 30–50nm. Still another sample, Al2O3-R is composed of nanorods with diameters of 6–8nm and lengths of 40–80nm. In addition, Al2O3-F consisted of nanofibers, with an average diameter of 5–6nm and lengths of 80–300nm. Combined with the pore size distribution results, it can be inferred that for nanostructured alumina, with bimodal pore size distributions, the small pores were produced via random accumulation of spherical particles and the large pores were produced from that of nanorods or nanofibres. However, the random mixing of the long nanofibers led to a bird nest-like structure, with an irregular and broad pore size distribution. A representative TEM image of the commercial alumina Al2O3-C is shown in Fig. 3e, which shows rod-like particles that are closely arranged in a worm-like porous network. 3.2 Characterization of catalyst 3.2.1 X-ray powder diffraction XRD X-ray diffraction profiles of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 , which show diffraction peaks indexed both to the Al2O3 support and to the Co3O4 phase [15]. Borg et al. [19] reported that the Co3O4 crystallite size increased with increasing Al2O3 pore sizes. However, Martínez et al. [14] reported that the final cobalt dispersion is mainly determined by the specific surface area of the alumina support, rather than by its pore size. In our work, the sizes of the Co3O4 crystallites calculated from XRD data using the Scherrer formula are shown in Table 1. The size of cobalt oxide crystallites on Al2O3-F (with broad distribution have large pore at 20nm) is 15.6nm. On the other hand, while the cobalt oxide crystallites sizes on Al2O3-R, Al2O3-H and Al2O3-P, with bimodal pore structure, have similar small pores at 7nm and various large pores at 20–50nm, cobalt oxide crystallites size increased with the increase of the large pores. This is consistent with Borg's [19] result, that the Co3O4 particle sizes were controlled by the support pore size. However, the Al2O3-C with unimodal pore size distribution has smaller pore sizes and lower surface area among the various samples. The supported catalyst has the intermediate cobalt oxide crystallite size at 14.1nm. Thus, the pore structure of support which is dependent upon the morphology and stacking of the primary particle of nanostructured alumina also influences the initial cobalt oxide crystallite dispersion. 3.2.2 Nitrogen adsorption–desorption The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore distribution of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . It is noticed that the hysteresis loops and pore distributions of the catalysts have been changed from that of the parent alumina support for Co/Al2O3-P, Co/Al2O3-H and Co/Al2O3-R. As a result, the pore structure of the alumina has been changed after cobalt loading, as confirmed by the TEM images (Fig. 3f–h). The arrangement of spherical alumina nanoparticles becomes closer. However, Co/Al2O3-F retained the pore sizes at 6.9–25.8nm and Co/Al2O3-C retained the pore size at 7.4nm. These supports retained their pore structures after the cobalt loading, as confirmed by the TEM images (Fig. 3i and j). Please note the arrangement of original alumina particles has not been changed significantly. These results indicated Co/Al2O3-F, with bird nest-like structures and Co/Al2O3-C, with closely arranged primary particles have stable pore structures. The surface area and pore volume of the catalysts are listed in Table 1. The supported cobalt catalysts show decreased surface area and pore volume, suggesting that parts of the cobalt species enter into the pores of the supports. It is also noted that the reductions in pore volume in the loaded catalysts, Co/Al2O3-P, Co/Al2O3-H and Co/Al2O3-R are more than that of Co/Al2O3-F and Co/Al2O3-C, indicating that the original alumina nanoparticles, in which they were closely arranged, caused a decrease in pore volume. 3.2.3 Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) TPR profiles of the prepared catalysts are shown in Fig. 6 . Three reduction peaks are observed at temperature ranges of <563, 563–633 and >633K, for all the catalysts. The small peak below 563K, could be attributed to the reductive decomposition of residual Co(NO3)2 and amorphous CoO(OH) species [20]. The second peak at 563–633K is attributed to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO. The broad high temperature reduction peak (>633K) is ascribed to the subsequent reduction of CoO to Co0. The reducibility of the supported cobalt catalysts was affected by cobalt particle size [21] and metal-support interaction [12]. The TPR pattern of Co/Al2O3-C, Co/Al2O3-P and Co/Al2O3-F catalysts, shows a shoulder peak at 645K, which may be due to the reduction of large CoO particle to Co0. The second reduction peak for all five catalysts was located in a marrow region about 600K. It is suggested that the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO is not affected by the nature of the catalyst. A similar conclusion has been reported by Borg et al. [22]. The third reduction peak for Co/Al2O3-F and Co/Al2O3-C catalysts at lower temperatures than that of the other catalysts was perhaps due to the larger CoO particles on the catalysts interacting more weakly with the support. However, a shoulder peak at 920K, for Co/Al2O3-F is higher than that for Co/Al2O3-C. It is indicative that the metal-support interaction is stronger for Co/Al2O3-F than for Co/Al2O3-C catalysts. Comparing the temperature of the third peak of all catalysts, the metal-support interaction of all catalysts increased in the sequence: Co/Al2O3-C, <Co/Al2O3-F, <Co/Al2O3-P, <Co/Al2O3-H, <Co/Al2O3-R. 3.2.4 H2-temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD) and O2 pulse reoxidation Table 3 presents the H2-temperature programmed desorption and O2 pulse re-oxidation results for the catalysts after reduction at 723K, for 10h. It is clearly seen that the support affected the catalysts reducibility regarding cobalt dispersion and cobalt particle size. The degree of reduction decreased in the sequence: Co/Al2O3-C, >Co/Al2O3-F, >Co/Al2O3-P, >Co/Al2O3-H and >Co/Al2O3-R. The catalyst's reducibility data is in agreement with the TPR results. The H2 chemisorption results showed that nanostructured alumina supported catalysts have higher cobalt dispersion and smaller cobalt metal particle sizes compared with Co/Al2O3-C. However, these catalysts have similar or larger average cobalt oxide sizes than Co/Al2O3-C as determined by XRD. This is perhaps because during the preparation of the nanostructured alumina catalysts, more cobalt species remained undecomposed as shown in the TPR results. These cobalt species experienced enhanced metal-support interactions resulting in more small cobalt particles in the support's pores after reduction. The direct reduction of the cobalt nitrate can improve the dispersion of the catalysts [4]. The mean metal Co particle sizes derived from XRD and H2 chemisorption measurements for catalysts supported on R, H, and P nanostructured aluminas show larger discrepancies than Co/Al2O3-F and Co/Al2O3-C catalysts. There may be two reasons: (1) The very small cobalt oxide particles may be missed by XRD due to significant XRD line broadening [2]. Compared with the catalysts Co/Al2O3-F and Co/Al2O3-C, the catalysts Co/Al2O3-R, Co/Al2O3-H, and Co/Al2O3-P may have more smaller Co nanoparticles located in the smaller mesopores would hardly be detected by XRD. (2) In the catalyst reduction process, the change in cobalt particle size varies due to the different structures of the catalysts perhaps the bimodal distribution of Co/Al2O3-F may have also contributed to the larger discrepancy in particle size determined by the two methods. Co particle size could be determined by the porosity of the support [5,19]. However, in our work, the nanostructured alumina supported catalysts represent various reconstructured pore structures, Therefore, we believe the porosity of the catalysts have larger impact on the final cobalt metal particle size. As shown in Fig. 7A the average cobalt metal particle size for the Co/Al2O3-R, Co/Al2O3-H, Co/Al2O3-P and Co/Al2O3-C catalysts, continuously increases with catalyst average pore sizes except for Co/Al2O3-F. However, as shown in Fig. 7B, only the small pore at 6.9nm, which appear after the cobalt loading, was considered for Co/Al2O3-F, the linear relation between the cobalt metal particle size and catalyst BJH pore sizes is maintained. The cobalt metal particle sizes increased significantly with increasing pore size which is in agreement with our previous result [23]. This may indicate that the pore size of catalysts influences the final cobalt crystallite dispersion. 3.3 Activity and selectivity of catalysts in Fischer–Tropsch synthesis The CO conversion over the catalysts is presented in Fig. 8 and Table 4 . The nanostructured alumina supported catalysts improved the catalytic activity by 20–30%, compared with the commercial alumina supported catalysts. It is generally accepted that the activity of cobalt catalysts for FTS is dependent upon the amount of the exposed active metal cobalt sites. The amount of exposed active metal cobalt sites depended upon the metal cobalt particle sizes and reducibility. The turnover frequency (TOF) of these catalysts, based upon H2 chemisorption and CO initial conversions, have also been calculated. The relationship between cobalt particle sizes and turnover frequency is show in Fig. 9 . As can be seen, the initial activity of FTS decreases as the size of cobalt particles is increased from 6.6 to 11.7nm, while the TOF is relatively unchanged for these cobalt catalysts, with cobalt particle sizes in the range of 6–12nm. The effect of cobalt particle size on TOF of FTS has been investigated previously [8]. It has been suggested that the intrinsic site reaction rate remained invariant for cobalt particle sizes larger than 6–8nm. Thus, constant turnover frequency for the catalysts, suggests that the decrease in the initial activity of FTS, was caused by a decrease in the number of active cobalt sites of the catalysts. Consequently, it is suggested that the support affected the rate of FTS through affecting the cobalt dispersion and catalyst reducibility. The performance of the catalysts at steady state (100h) is summarized in Table 4. The alumina nanofiber catalyst showed the highest FT activity among the catalysts studied. Alumina nanofiber supported catalysts have high activity due to its stability during reaction, as seen from Fig. 8. Sintering is one of the main deactivation mechanisms for cobalt based FTS catalysts [24], which is highly influenced by the support. The mobility of the cobalt crystals on various supports contributes significantly to the sintering behavior [25]. The mobility of the active metal particles may be affected by the crystal structure and the nature of the site. It has been suggested that the three-dimensional cobalt aggregates were formed from the interlocking of alumina crystallites and cobalt oxide [26,27]. Fig. 10a and b presents the TEM results of the catalysts Co/Al2O3-P and Co/Al2O3-F, after reduction at 723K under H2 for 10h and passivation in a flow of 1% O2/He. Fig. 10c and d presents the TEM results of the catalysts Co/Al2O3-P and Co/Al2O3-F, after use at 483K for 110h. The stability of the alumina nanofiber supported catalysts, may be due to the presence of the large, stable and interconnected, bird nest-like pore structures, which could reduce the contact between the cobalt species aggregates. Thus, the distances between the cobalt crystallites after reduction on bird nest-like structures were farther than that of other close structures (see Fig. 10a and b), such as reconstructured nanostructured alumina and commercial alumina, and the sintering of the metallic phases during reaction was subdued (see Fig. 10c and d). The distances between the cobalt crystallites were nearly unchanged for unused and after used catalysts Co/Al2O3-F (see Fig. 10b and d). Moreover, the presence of the stable, larger pores or bimodal pore size distribution [28,29] in Co/Al2O3-F, is likely to facilitate the diffusion of reactants and products decreasing the accumulation of high molecular weight carbon species, hence increasing the accessibility of cobalt active sites for the reaction. The selectivity data are displayed in Table 4. Compared with Co/Al2O3-C, the nanostructured alumina supported catalysts show higher C5+ selectivity and lower CH4 selectivity, as well as higher CO conversion. The reason may be that higher CO conversion led to a higher selectivity resulting in heavier hydrocarbons [12]. The products selectivities for the Co/Al2O3-P, Co/Al2O3-H and Co/Al2O3-R catalysts, showed a small difference between the different supports. However, the Co/Al2O3-F catalyst showed similar activity, but different selectivity suggests that the change in methane and C5+ selectivity are dependent upon the size of cobalt crystallites and catalyst's pores. This is similar to what has been reported [5,30], that higher methane selectivity was observed on catalysts with narrow pore and small cobalt particles. 4 Conclusion Various morphologies of nanostructured aluminas were synthesized using alumina nitrate. The effect of morphology of the nanostructured alumina supported cobalt catalysts on selectively and activity for FTS reaction have been investigated. The support's morphology of the nanostructured alumina significantly influenced the catalytic performance. The pore structures of the nanostructured alumina, which is dependent upon the morphology and stacking of the primary particle, have undergone reconstruction during the catalyst preparation resulting in more exposed cobalt active sites on the catalyst. Among the nanostructured alumina, the nanofiber supported catalyst has improved stability through the large, stable and interconnected bird nest-like pore structures with large cobalt particle size and showed the best catalytic performance. coredata.dc:description: Nanostructured aluminas with controllable morphologies were prepared and used as support of cobalt catalysts for Fischer–Tropsch synthesis. The supported cobalt catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method and characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), temperature programmed reduction (TPR), N2 adsorption–desorption, hydrogen chemisorption and oxygen titration. Catalytic activity of the cobalt catalysts for Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) was evaluated on a fixed bed reactor. It was found that the nanostructured alumina supports undergo reconstruction during the catalyst preparation resulting in catalysts having high dispersion after reduction. The cobalt catalyst supported on the nanostructured alumina increased the CO conversion by 20–30%, compared to commercial alumina. Among the nanostructured catalysts, the alumina nanorods supported catalyst, shows the best dispersion and highest CO initial conversion. Our work disclosed that the alumina nanofibers supported catalysts have larger, stable and interconnected bird nest-like pores. In addition, the structure exhibited higher stability and lower methane selectivity for FTS.
coredata.dc:title: Fischer–Tropsch synthesis over cobalt catalysts supported on nanostructured alumina with various morphologies
